results_summary: The study reported a very large clinical effect of the supplement, larger than any other known product for osteoarthritis, with an effect size above 0.5, though the trial had a high risk of bias due to post-study registration and potential detection bias from the fish taste.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish-oil supplements on vascular function and metabolic profiles in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Fish-oil supplementation significantly reduced serum triglycerides but did not improve vascular function, metabolic profiles, inflammation, or oxidative stress. However, it improved renal function as indicated by lower serum creatinine levels.
population_specificity: 97 Type 2 diabetes mellitus patients without prior cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a reusable fish-shaped iron ingot could effectively address iron-deficiency anaemia (IDA) in rural Cambodian women by leaching iron into food during cooking.
results_summary: The iron ingot increased blood iron levels in the short term (3 months) but did not sustain this effect at 6 months, with haemoglobin and serum iron levels declining in all groups by the study's end. The intervention showed temporary efficacy but lacked long-term benefits.
population_specificity: Rural women (n = 189) in Preak Ruessei, Kandal Province, Cambodia.
effective_dosage: Daily use of the iron ingot during cooking (specific iron leaching amount not quantified).
study_duration: 6 months (measurements at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to clinical practice guidelines regarding the use of fish oil-enriched enteral formulas in intensive care units.
results_summary: The study found poor adherence to recommendations for the use of enteral formulas enriched with fish oils, indicating suboptimal implementation despite guideline recommendations. No specific efficacy outcomes related to fish oils were detailed.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated adult patients in intensive care units (n=2,946).
study_duration: Data collected from ICU admission to discharge or up to 12 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a cetoleic acid-rich fish oil (CRO) on the omega-3 index and skin inflammation markers.
results_summary: The CRO increased the omega-3 index similarly to oils with higher omega-3 content and reduced skin erythema, a marker of inflammation.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (55 in CetoIndex, 28 women in Optihud).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of fish oil, specifically DHA, on heart rate variability (HRV) and arterial compliance in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: Fish oil did not affect blood pressure, small artery compliance, or heart rate but improved large artery compliance and reduced the low frequency:high frequency ratio of HRV, suggesting enhanced arterial function and cardiac autonomic regulation.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (36 males, 31 females; average age 53 years; BMI 31.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 2 g/d, 4 g/d, or 6 g/d of fish oil (260 mg DHA + 60 mg EPA per gram).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary supplementation with a DHA-rich fish oil influenced the release of PGF(2alpha) from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) in Alzheimer's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that DHA-rich fish oil supplementation significantly increased plasma DHA and EPA levels and reduced PGF(2alpha) release from LPS-stimulated PBMC, correlating with decreased inflammatory markers like IL-6 and IL-1(beta). No changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 174 Alzheimer's disease patients (subset of 21 analyzed for PBMC response).
effective_dosage: 1.7 g DHA plus 0.6 g EPA daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics and metabolite profiles of three different fish oil formulations (standard softgels, enteric-coated softgels, and a micellar formulation) in healthy participants.
results_summary: The micellar formulation (LMF) showed significantly higher blood concentrations of n-3 FAs and certain anti-inflammatory metabolites compared to the other formulations, despite a lower administered dose. LMF also led to a significant decrease in serum triglycerides (~20%), while no significant changes were observed in other lipid biomarkers.
population_specificity: 12 healthy participants
effective_dosage: STD and ENT: 600 mg n-3 FA; LMF: 374 mg n-3 FA
study_duration: 24 hours for pharmacokinetics, up to 120 hours for lipid monitoring

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether menhaden fish oil (FO) could suppress LPS-induced neuroinflammation and cognitive impairment in diabetic animals.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation (1 g/kg and 3 g/kg) significantly reduced hyperglycemia, brain inflammation, and neuronal damage in diabetic animals, while also improving cognitive performance in the Y-maze test.
population_specificity: Diabetic male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish oil and vitamin E supplementation on oxidative status and immune responses in weanling piglets before and after an E. coli challenge.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation, combined with vitamin E, reduced lipid peroxidation and improved antioxidative status and immune responses post-E. coli challenge, though hemp oil showed greater effects on antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Weanling piglets (n=24) from two litters.
effective_dosage: 1 mL/day of fish oil or hemp oil with 60 mg natural vitamin E/mL oil.
study_duration: 18 days (from day 10 to day 28 of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antimicrobial abilities of fish oil components (DHA, EPA, and resolvins) against medically relevant microorganisms, including drug-resistant strains.
results_summary: DHA and EPA were effective against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, though some drug-resistant strains were unaffected. Resolvins only inhibited E. coli.
population_specificity: Medically relevant microorganisms, including MRSA and carbapenem-resistant E. coli.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation in fathers could mitigate the intergenerational development of obesity and improve metabolic health in offspring.
results_summary: Offspring of fathers supplemented with fish oil showed lower body weight, improved insulin tolerance, altered inflammatory markers, increased fatty acid oxidation, and reduced fatty acid synthesis.
population_specificity: Male mice fed a high-fat or low-fat diet, and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining fish oil (or its components DHA and EPA) with natural products on cognitive function protection.
results_summary: Clinical trials showed no advanced effects of combining fish oil with curcumin or vitamin E on cognitive function, though preclinical studies suggested potential benefits for addressing neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and neuronal survival.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract mentions clinical trials and preclinical studies without detailing participant demographics).
study_duration: 16 weeks (for one trial involving vitamin E)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of incremental levels of n-3 fatty acids from fish oil in starter feed on the growth and metabolic performance of milk-fed calves.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in growth, metabolic performance, or behavioral parameters between calves fed fish oil and those fed palm fatty acids, suggesting that replacing palm fatty acids with fish oil at moderate levels (~3% of DM) does not affect calf performance under non-challenged conditions.
population_specificity: Female milk-fed calves (30 individuals, 39.4 ± 3.1 kg body weight).
effective_dosage: 1.9% fish oil (PFO) and 3.9% fish oil (FO) in starter feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the need for a fish oil deprescribing process and evaluate the effectiveness of student pharmacists in deprescribing fish oil in primary care settings.
results_summary: The study identified 106 patients prescribed fish oil, with 68 included after exclusions. 76.2% of patients accepted at least one therapy modification offered by pharmacy students, suggesting a role for deprescribing initiatives.
population_specificity: Older adults in primary care clinic patient panels prescribed fish oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term metabolic health effects of maternal fish oil (n-3 LCPUFA) supplementation during pregnancy on offspring at age 10 years.
results_summary: Children whose mothers received fish oil supplementation had higher BMI, increased risk of overweight, and a tendency toward higher fat percentage and metabolic syndrome scores compared to controls. The study suggests potential adverse health effects from n-3 LCPUFA supplementation during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant females and their offspring from the Copenhagen Prospective Studies on Asthma in Childhood mother-child cohort.
study_duration: From pregnancy week 24 until 1 week after birth

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of omega-3 fatty acids (fish oil) in reducing allergic rhinitis symptoms and histopathological changes in a rat model.
results_summary: Fish oil significantly reduced allergic rhinitis symptoms (e.g., nasal scratching, sneezing) and prevented inflammatory changes in nasal mucosa. Histological improvements included reduced goblet cell hyperplasia and inflammatory cell infiltration compared to controls.
population_specificity: Wistar Hannover rats (250-350 g) with induced allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation, combined with a hypocaloric diet, could influence weight loss, iron profiles, and n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid levels in middle-aged women with obesity and metabolic abnormalities.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation increased bioavailable iron in women with moderate pretreatment hemoglobin levels and partially prevented iron reduction in those with low hemoglobin levels. Dietary weight loss improved erythrocyte membrane fatty acid profiles, particularly in women with high pretreatment hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older women with obesity and at least two metabolic abnormalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation could modify the sRANKL/osteoprotegerin ratio and reduce inflammatory markers like TNFalpha in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation increased osteoprotegerin levels, decreased sRANKL, TNFalpha, and the sRANKL/osteoprotegerin ratio, suggesting a reduction in inflammatory response. A significant positive correlation was found between the sRANKL/osteoprotegerin ratio and TNFalpha levels in the treated group.
population_specificity: 83 female patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and toxicity of a VLCFA-enriched fish oil supplement (EPAX® Evolve 05) through repeat-dose studies in rodents.
results_summary: The study found transient lipid accumulation in kidneys and liver, which was not dose-related and resolved in longer-term studies. No treatment-related adverse effects were observed in functional, biochemical, or histological assessments, with a NOAEL of 1200 mg VLCFA/kg b.w./day.
population_specificity: Mice and rats
effective_dosage: Up to 1200 mg VLCFA/kg body weight/day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing fishmeal and fish oil with poultry byproduct meal and mixed oil on growth performance, body composition, and muscle quality in tiger puffer.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in growth performance or body composition when fish oil was replaced with mixed oil, though muscle flavor compounds were altered. Omega-3 sparing effects were observed with mixed oil supplementation.
population_specificity: Farmed tiger puffer (Takifugu rubripes) with an initial average body weight of 14.29 g.
effective_dosage: 5% of the diet as added oil (either fish oil or mixed oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physical and oxidative stability of fish oil-in-water emulsions when stabilized with protein hydrolysates from olive and sunflower seeds.
results_summary: Sunflower seed hydrolysates at 5% degree of hydrolysis provided the highest physical stability and effectively retarded lipid oxidation in fish oil emulsions over a 7-day storage period. Olive seed hydrolysates also showed stability but were less effective than sunflower seed hydrolysates.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on emulsions)
effective_dosage: 50 g kg-1 fish oil-in-water emulsions with 20 g kg-1 protein hydrolysates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-pressure-microfluidization (HPM)-treated sodium caseinate (CS) complexed with EGCG could improve the stability of fish oil emulsions.
results_summary: HPM treatment (especially at 80 MPa) altered CS's secondary structure, and the 80 MPa-PCS-EGCG complex showed the best emulsifying and antioxidant activities. The complex also formed a thicker interface layer, protecting fish oil from oxygen, temperature, and ion concentration effects, and delayed free fatty acid release during in vitro digestion.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of fish-oil-capsule supplementation on glycemic and lipid profiles in pregnant women.
results_summary: Overall, fish-oil supplementation had no significant effect on glycemic or lipid parameters compared to placebo. However, subgroup analyses showed beneficial effects on insulin and HOMA-IR indices in pregnant women with diabetes mellitus and at EPA dosages below 200 mg.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, with specific subgroup analysis on those with diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: EPA dosages below 200 mg were noted as effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high supplementation of n-3 LCPUFAs from fish oil could lower the prevalence and severity of oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OIPN) in colorectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so definitive results are not yet available, but the hypothesis is that fish oil supplementation will reduce OIPN prevalence and severity, improving quality of life and treatment adherence.
population_specificity: Patients eligible to receive adjuvant oxaliplatin after colorectal cancer surgery (n=120).
effective_dosage: Not specified (fish oil capsules containing n-3 LCPUFAs daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective, hypolipidemic, and aortic morphometric effects of omega-3-rich fish oil in hypercholesterolemic mice.
results_summary: Fish oil showed a protective effect on liver tissue (reducing hepatitis and necrosis) but did not significantly improve lipid profiles or aortic morphometry. The vessel wall thickness remained unchanged across groups.
population_specificity: Male BALB/c mice (Mus musculus) with induced hypercholesterolemia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentioned as "fish oil" supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fish oil supplementation is cardioprotective due to beneficial modifications in HDL particles.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation improved HDL's sterol efflux capacity by modifying its proteome and lipidome, increasing cholesterol efflux capacity, and reducing inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Seven fish oil-naïve subjects without a history of cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: 1125 mg EPA and 875 mg DHA daily.
study_duration: 30 days of supplementation followed by a 30-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation with omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) reduces the rate of serious cardiovascular events in hemodialysis patients compared to placebo.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with kidney failure on replacement therapy (KFRT) in Canada and Australia.
study_duration: Expected intervention period of at least 3.5 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if paternal fish oil supplementation during the pre-conceptional period could improve metabolic health, specifically liver function, in offspring of obese fathers.
results_summary: Paternal fish oil supplementation improved glucose tolerance, reduced inflammation and fatty acid synthesis biomarkers, and increased fatty acid oxidation biomarkers in offspring liver compared to offspring of high-fat diet fathers without supplementation.
population_specificity: Male mice fed high-fat diets and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the short-term effects of a combined nutraceutical containing fish oil (PUFAs) and red yeast rice on plasma lipids, hsCRP, and endothelial function in healthy subjects with suboptimal LDL-cholesterolaemia.
results_summary: The combined supplement significantly reduced LDL-C (17.3%), total cholesterol (12.1%), apoB (22.3%), and hsCRP (14.9%), while improving endothelial function (5.0% increase in pulse volume change). The supplement was well tolerated with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with suboptimal LDL-cholesterolaemia.
effective_dosage: 588 mg of fish oil (standardized to 350 mg EPA and 45 mg DHA) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the bioavailability and physiological effects of fish oil-derived VLCPUFAs (C24-28) in mice, focusing on cardiometabolic and eye health benefits.
results_summary: VLCPUFAs from fish oil were effectively absorbed and incorporated into key tissues, leading to improved cardiometabolic markers, enhanced retinal function, and visual performance, along with modulation of PPAR signaling pathways.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of fish oil supplementation in pregnant Awassi ewes on dam performance, offspring birth weight, colostrum and milk quality, and fatty acid composition in milk.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation during late pregnancy (POFO treatment) increased birth weight, colostrum IgG concentration, and milk PUFA levels but reduced colostrum production and milk fat/protein percentages.
population_specificity: Pregnant Awassi ewes (average BW 57 ± 1.5 kg, age 3.5 ± 1.2 years).
effective_dosage: 2.4% of dietary DM (early gestation, first 65 days), then 2.1% DM (late gestation, day 65 to lambing).
study_duration: From day 0 to day 150 of pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil combined with resistance exercise training improves physical function and reduces cardiometabolic risk factors in healthy older women.
results_summary: Fish oil combined with resistance training significantly improved handgrip strength, reduced blood pressure, triglycerides, inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α and IL-6), and oxidative stress markers (MDA and 8-OHdG), while resistance training alone did not show these effects.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (postmenopausal)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) is involved in the repair of oxidative damage induced by oxidized fish oil (OFO) in Litopenaeus vannamei by sulforaphane (SFN).
results_summary: SFN treatment increased HO-1 expression, upregulated antioxidant-related genes, stabilized apoptosis genes, and repaired oxidative damage in hepatopancreas. Knocking down HO-1 worsened oxidative damage, while SFN supplementation mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: Litopenaeus vannamei (Pacific whiteleg shrimp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Carcharhinus Bleekeri (Shark Fish) oil on learning and memory functions in scopolamine-induced amnesia in rats.
results_summary: Fish oil significantly improved locomotor and memory-enhancing activities in scopolamine-induced amnesic rats, restored acetylcholine concentration in the hippocampus, and prevented monoamine degradation. Histological analysis showed that fish oil treatment reversed cellular distortion in the hippocampus caused by scopolamine.
population_specificity: Male Albino rats with scopolamine-induced amnesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between fish oil supplementation and its effects on depression, neuroinflammation, and cognitive function in an aging-related depression animal model.
results_summary: Fish oil intake improved depressive-like symptoms and cognitive impairment, reduced proinflammatory cytokine expression, activated glial cells, and increased interleukin-10 levels in the prefrontal cortex. It also ameliorated abnormal neurobehaviors and neuroinflammation while elevating serotonin levels in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats in an aging-related depression animal model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fatty acid composition of enteral nutrition formulas with added fish oil and compare them with label claims.
results_summary: The study found discrepancies between the actual fatty acid content and label claims, with some samples not meeting recommended ratios for PUFA/SFA and n-6/n-3 fatty acids. EPA + DHA content was positively correlated with diet cost, and significant differences were observed between analyzed and labeled values for various fatty acids.
population_specificity: Enteral nutrition formulas used in a public hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether n-3 PUFA supplementation (fish oil) could modulate miRNA-122 and FGF-21 levels and improve liver fibrosis and steatosis in individuals with NAFLD.
results_summary: The abstract describes a study protocol, so no results are reported yet. The study will assess the effects of fish oil supplementation on liver fibrosis, steatosis, and related biomarkers in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged >19 years with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
effective_dosage: 4 g/day of fish oil (2100 mg EPA and 924 mg DHA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic use of DHA-rich fish oil could protect against experimental cerebral malaria (CM) by reducing mechanical and immunological damage caused by Plasmodium berghei ANKA infection.
results_summary: High doses of DHA-rich fish oil (3.0 and 6.0 g/kg body weight) significantly improved survival rates (60% and 80%, respectively) in mice with CM, reduced parasite load during critical infection periods, and prevented brain hemorrhage, vascular occlusion, and blood-brain barrier damage. The treatment also modulated immune responses, showing anti-inflammatory effects in the brain and altered leukocyte counts in the spleen.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA.
study_duration: Started 15 days prior to infection and continued until the end of the study (20 days post-infection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if cetoleic acid (CA), a long-chain MUFA found in pelagic fish, could lower circulating total cholesterol (TC) in rodents, potentially reducing CVD risk.
results_summary: Consumption of CA-rich fish oils and concentrates significantly lowered circulating TC in rodents (mean difference -0.65 mmol/l), though statistical heterogeneity was high (I² = 87%). The risk of bias was unclear due to limited reporting in the SYRCLE's tool.
population_specificity: Rodents (288 subjects across 12 studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which fish oil supplementation during pregnancy reduces the risk of persistent wheeze or asthma in children.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation reduced non-atopic asthma risk by 73% and infections by 16% in children, with protective effects on atopic asthma dependent on maternal genetics and baseline fatty acid levels.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children followed until age 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil consumption on insulin resistance and pancreatic islet dysfunction in a diabetic rat model.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation reduced hyperglycemia, improved insulin sensitivity (HOMA-IR), and enhanced pancreatic islet structure in STZ-induced diabetic rats, with higher doses (3 g/kg) showing more pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: STZ-induced diabetic rats (n = 30, divided into five groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical trials and observational studies to investigate the benefits of fish oil on the cardiovascular system and its proposed underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Fish oil supplements were found to reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases, though the extent of reduction and underlying mechanisms require further clarification. The study reviewed existing literature but did not present new experimental data.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypertriglyceridemia or at risk of cardiovascular disease (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer efficacy of linoelaidic acid, a conjugated fatty acid derived from marine fish (Opisthopterus tardoore), in human breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7).
results_summary: Linoelaidic acid demonstrated dose-dependent anticancer activity, reducing MCF-7 cell viability by 81.82% at 5 µM, increasing TNF-α and IL-1ra levels, and inducing oxidative stress and apoptosis via protein expression changes (p53, IL-10, IL-1ra).
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acids (fish oil) could prevent postoperative delirium (POD) in aged mice by reducing inflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids significantly reduced POD-like behavior, systemic inflammation, neuroinflammation, and oxidative stress in aged mice after surgery. The treatment also lowered proinflammatory cytokines and improved antioxidant responses in the brain.
population_specificity: Aged mice undergoing laparotomy (surgical procedure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of fish oil capsules, treated with flavoring agents, on lactation performance, rumen fatty acids content, and milk fatty acid enrichment in dairy cows.
results_summary: Feeding fish oil capsules reduced milk fat concentration and yield, increased trans C18:1 isomers and DHA in rumen and milk fat, but had no effect on overall animal performance or milk composition. Treated capsules marginally prevented fish oil release in the rumen due to reduced abrasion resistance.
population_specificity: Multiparous Holstein and Jersey cows with ruminal fistulas.
effective_dosage: 200 or 180 capsules per cow/day (untreated or treated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil, alone or combined with probiotics, could lower the risk of allergic diseases in infants when administered from early pregnancy onwards.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the odds of allergic diseases or atopy in infants across the intervention groups, indicating fish oil did not lower the risk of these conditions. The probiotic intervention alone showed a reduction in recurrent wheezing at 24 months, but fish oil had no such effect.
population_specificity: Women in early pregnancy and their infants up to 24 months postpartum.
effective_dosage: 1.9 g docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and 0.22 g eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) daily.
study_duration: From randomization in early pregnancy up to 6 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil (n-3 PUFAs) could effectively reduce depressive symptoms in young people with major depressive disorder when used as an adjunct to cognitive behavioral case management.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in depressive symptom reduction between the fish oil and placebo groups, with similar adverse event profiles. Erythrocyte n-3 PUFA levels were not associated with depression severity.
population_specificity: 15- to 25-year-old individuals with major depressive disorder seeking care in Australian mental health services.
effective_dosage: 840 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 560 mg docosahexaenoic acid daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral supplementations, including fish oil, in treating depression among children, preadolescents, and adolescents.
results_summary: Most studies indicated that dietary interventions, including fish oil, provided positive outcomes in reducing depression symptoms. However, the effectiveness of fish oil as a monotherapy or combined treatment remains understudied.
population_specificity: Children, preadolescents, and adolescents diagnosed with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether selenium (Se) could alleviate oxidized fish oil (OFO)-induced lipotoxicity and mitochondrial dysfunction in yellow catfish, a model for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: High dietary Se supplementation reduced OFO-induced lipotoxicity, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial injury by stabilizing Pparα via the Txnrd2-mtROS-Usp4 pathway, improving mitochondrial fatty acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Yellow catfish and their hepatocytes (as a model for NAFLD).
effective_dosage: High dietary Se supplementation (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early supplementation with fish oil, alone or combined with antioxidants, could mitigate lung injury and improve biomarkers of alveolarization and microvascular maturation in neonatal rats exposed to intermittent hypoxia.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation reduced lung damage and improved alveolarization in neonatal rats exposed to intermittent hypoxia. Combined with CoQ10, it enhanced angiogenesis markers (VEGF165 and CD31) and alveolarization, though some hemorrhage was observed.
population_specificity: Extremely preterm neonatal rat pups (from birth to postnatal day 21).
study_duration: From birth (P0) to postnatal day 14 (P14), followed by observation until P21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil supplementation on male rabbits' productivity, biochemical, and physiological characteristics.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in cholesterol levels in rabbits treated with fish oil compared to the control group, though the impact on other features was small. The results suggest that fish oil at 0.75 ml or 1.5 ml daily for 60 days improves biochemical and hematological outcomes.
population_specificity: Local male rabbits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a combination of fish oil, probiotics, and glutamine could reduce psychological distress and improve gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with high distress and gut discomfort.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect on psychological distress or perceived stress, but a significant reduction in gastrointestinal symptoms was observed. The combination of fish oil, probiotics, and glutamine did not meet the primary psychological outcome but improved gut health.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 in Australia with mild gastrointestinal discomfort and high psychological distress (K10 score 16-30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alaska pollack protein (APP) intake without an exercise program could prevent neuromuscular dysfunction in community-dwelling older adults performing normal daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that while muscle strength, thickness, and motor function did not change, the motor unit firing rate declined significantly in the control group but not in the APP group, suggesting APP may help maintain neuromuscular properties.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential roles of fish oil's active ingredients in delaying glaucoma progression by lowering intraocular pressure, regulating blood supply, alleviating inflammation, and reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study suggests fish oil may benefit glaucoma patients by normalizing omega-3 fatty acid levels, potentially improving intraocular pressure, blood flow, inflammation, and oxidative stress, though its exact mechanisms and efficacy remain unclear.
population_specificity: Glaucoma patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early supplementation with fish oil reduces the severity of intermittent hypoxia-induced retinopathy in extremely low gestational-age neonates.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation showed beneficial effects in reducing oxidative stress and retinopathy caused by intermittent hypoxia, though CoQ10 provided superior benefits. The effects were linked to lower retinal antioxidants and angiogenesis biomarkers.
population_specificity: Extremely low gestational-age rat pups exposed to neonatal intermittent hypoxia.
effective_dosage: Daily oral fish oil (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: 14 days of supplementation followed by 7 days of recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining fish oil (EPA/DHA) and cocoa flavanols improves cognitive performance and brain structures in older adults with memory complaints.
results_summary: The combined intervention showed no significant improvement in cognitive outcomes, except for declines in reaction time variability, alertness, and executive function. It increased plasma HDL and glucose while reducing triglycerides, with no effect on BDNF.
population_specificity: Older adults with subjective cognitive impairment or mild cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: 1.1 g/d DHA and 0.4 g/d EPA from fish oil, plus 500 mg/d flavan-3-ols from dark chocolate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether fish oil-derived ω-3 PUFAs, alone or combined with wheat oligopeptide, could prevent and reverse sarcopenia in aging rats.
results_summary: Fish oil, especially when combined with wheat oligopeptide, significantly increased muscle mass and grip strength, reduced fat weight, and improved oxidative stress, anabolism, and inflammation in aging rats. The combination (400 mg/kg fish oil + 200 mg/kg wheat oligopeptide) was most effective.
population_specificity: 25-month-old Sprague-Dawley rats (aging model) and a young control group (6-month-old rats).
effective_dosage: Fish oil doses: 200, 400, or 800 mg/kg body weight daily; combination doses: 200+400, 400+200, or 800+100 mg/kg (fish oil + wheat oligopeptide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-power ultrasound treatments could improve the physicochemical, structural, and functional characteristics of fish protein hydrolysates (FPH) from Atlantic mackerel side streams, as well as assess their potential health-promoting properties.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment increased protein solubility and degree of hydrolysis, with higher power levels (450W and 600W) showing significant effects. The treatment also improved antioxidant activity and reduced oxidative stress markers in cellular models, suggesting potential health benefits.
population_specificity: Human intestinal Caco-2 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on ultrasound power levels: 300W, 450W, 600W for 10 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how fish protein hydrolysates, as an organic activator, influence microbial necromass and greenhouse gas emissions in soils with varying rice straw residue inputs.
results_summary: Fish protein hydrolysate (substituting 50% mineral N) under high straw input (HSF50) reduced CO2 emissions, enhanced microbial necromass C in soil organic C, and showed climate benefits without significantly affecting N2O emissions.
population_specificity: Agricultural soils with rice straw residue incorporation.
effective_dosage: 50% substitution of mineral N with fish protein hydrolysate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a bacterial-based single-cell protein (SCP) as an alternative to fish protein in zebrafish diets, focusing on growth, body composition, reproductive success, and gene expression.
results_summary: Zebrafish fed the bacterial protein diet showed equivalent weight gain and lower carcass lipid compared to those fed fish protein, with similar reproductive success. Gene expression differences indicated metabolic and cholesterol biosynthesis changes.
population_specificity: Juvenile Danio rerio (zebrafish) 31 days postfertilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lactic acid fermentation of kamaboko (heated surimi) could enhance proteolysis and functionality, particularly in generating bioactive peptides with ACE inhibitory activity.
results_summary: Fermentation with Lactobacillus helveticus JCM1004 degraded fish proteins (myosin heavy chain and actin), increased peptide content, and significantly elevated ACE inhibitory activity (approximately 70% in 200-fold diluted extract). Proteolysis was confined to the kamaboko surface, indicating surface area influences efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a novel bacterial single-cell protein (SCP) could serve as an effective alternative to traditional fish protein in standardized diets for zebrafish, focusing on growth, body composition, reproductive success, and liver transcriptomics.
results_summary: Zebrafish fed the SCP diet showed equivalent weight gain and reduced adiposity compared to those fed fish protein, with similar reproductive success. Liver transcriptomics indicated differential gene expression related to metabolism, cholesterol biosynthesis, and protein unfolding responses.
population_specificity: Juvenile Danio rerio (zebrafish) 31 days post-fertilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hydrolyzed fish protein and collagen on cell proliferation, the influence of minerals and metals, and whether dietary antioxidants could enhance proliferation.
results_summary: Hydrolyzed fish protein and collagen showed negative effects on Caco-2 cell proliferation at high concentrations, but pre-treatment with antioxidants (vitamin C, E, quercetin, resveratrol) increased proliferation. Metals (As, Cd, Hg, Pb) were found at negligible levels in bioavailable fractions.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Highest concentrations tested (specific amounts not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effects of incorporating fish protein isolates (Bullseye and Pacu) into oat-based cookies, focusing on nutritional, physical, textural, and sensory qualities.
results_summary: Cookies with 6% Pacu protein isolate had the highest protein content and essential amino acids, while 4% Bullseye protein isolate cookies had higher non-essential amino acids. Fish protein isolate-supplemented cookies showed improved microbial safety and texture compared to control cookies.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general population, as the study focused on food product development).
effective_dosage: 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 g/100 g of oat-based cookies.
study_duration: Not specified (likely a single baking and evaluation period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the production of fish protein hydrolysates (FPHs) and evaluate their bioactive properties, focusing on substrate treatments to enhance bioactivity and amino acid availability.
results_summary: The study found that FPHs exhibit bioactive properties such as antioxidant, antimicrobial, anticancer, and antihypertensive effects, which vary based on hydrolysis conditions, fish species, and peptide isolation methods. New technologies like high-pressure processing and encapsulation improved bioactivity and bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marine fish protein peptide (MFPP) could alleviate hyperuricemia (HUA) by reducing serum uric acid levels, attenuating kidney inflammation, and restoring gut microbiota balance.
results_summary: MFPP effectively reduced serum uric acid levels, attenuated kidney inflammation by lowering inflammatory factors (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-10), restored beneficial gut bacteria, repaired the intestinal barrier, and regulated genes involved in kidney function and uric acid metabolism.
population_specificity: HUA-induced rats
